titleInfo.title: Crystallization of Sustainable Precision Polyethylenes with Polar Functional Groups

name.namePart: Department of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering

mods:mods.abstract: Polyethylenes with functional groups placed at precise locations along the backbone serve as model systems for studying the effect of co-units on crystallization behavior of polymers. Good thermal stability and high crystallinity afforded by long methylene sequences between functional groups make these polymers attractive for potential future application as sustainable alternatives to commercial polyethylenes. This Dissertation provides a comprehensive study of the influence of acetal, carbonate, and ester functional groups on self-assembly, crystalline structure, and crystallization kinetics of these polyethylene-like materials with methylene spacer lengths ranging between 6 and 48. At a fixed functional group content, crystallization and melting temperatures increase with increasing functional group interaction strength (ester > carbonate > acetal) and decrease with increasing functional group content within each series. Polyesters and polycarbonates have an isomorphic, polyethylene-like unit cell, enabled by dipole-dipole interactions between functional groups of adjacent chains that serve to compensate for the enthalpic penalty introduced by the presence of functional groups in the crystals. In contrast, the relatively weaker interactions and the drive for gauche bonding near acetal groups in polyacetals leads to multiple crystalline polymorphic forms depending on the crystallization temperature. Although the polymers investigated herein maintain many characteristics of polyethylene, unique crystallization behaviors as a result of the functional groups, and furthermore their precise placement, are also observed, for instance unexpected minima in crystallization rate with increasing isothermal crystallization temperature. This distinctive feature of the crystallization behavior observed in polyacetals is driven by polymorphism, while in polyesters and polycarbonates, minima are attributed to quantized differences in lamellar thickness. Analyses presented in this Dissertation are relevant for discerning fundamentals of self-assembly that impact structure-property relationships of sustainable and recyclable polyethylene mimics.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
crystallization kinetics, long-spaced aliphatic polymers, polymer crystallization, semi-crystalline polymers
Rufina G. Alamo, Professor Directing Dissertation; Justin G. Kennemur, University Representative; Daniel T. Hallinan, Jr., Committee Member; Ralm G. Ricarte, Committee Member.
